Araria.title: Araria, Bihar
info: Located in the Seemanchal region bordering Nepal.
Carved out of Purnia district in 1990.
Known for its significant production of jute and maize.
The homeland of the famous Hindi writer Phanishwar Nath 'Renu'.
Its geography is influenced by the Kosi River, making it fertile yet prone to floods.

Arwal.title: Arwal, Bihar
info: Carved out from Jehanabad district in August 2001.
A smaller district situated on the banks of the Son River.
Its economy is heavily dependent on agriculture, with rice, wheat, and pulses as the main crops.
Part of the Magadh division, it has seen significant development in recent years.
Historically, the region was affected by Naxalism but is now largely peaceful.

Aurangabad.title: Aurangabad, Bihar
info: Often called the 'Chittorgarh of Bihar' due to its large Rajput population.
Historically significant and famous for the ancient Deo Sun Temple.
Located in the drought-prone Magadh region with a well-developed canal irrigation system.
A major cement production hub for Bihar.
It was a major center during the independence movement, particularly the Quit India Movement.

Banka.title: Banka, Bihar
info: Known for Mandar Hill, a granite hill of great mythological significance.
Mandar Hill is associated with the 'Samudra Manthan' (churning of the ocean) in Hindu mythology.
Carved out of Bhagalpur district in 1991.
Has significant forest cover and is known for Tussar silk production.
Its economy is a mix of agriculture and small-scale industries.

Begusarai.title: Begusarai, Bihar
info: Considered the 'Industrial Capital of Bihar'.
Home to major industries like the Barauni Oil Refinery and Thermal Power Station.
The birthplace of the national poet Ramdhari Singh 'Dinkar'.
Famous for Kanwar Lake, Asia's largest freshwater oxbow lake and a designated Ramsar site.
The Jai Mangla Garh temple is a significant local pilgrimage site.

Bhagalpur.title: Bhagalpur, Bihar
info: Famously known as the 'Silk City' of India for its Tussar silk industry.
A historic city on the banks of the Ganges, it was part of the ancient Anga Kingdom.
Was the seat of the Vikramshila University, a great center of Buddhist learning.
Home to the Vikramshila Gangetic Dolphin Sanctuary, dedicated to protecting the endangered Gangetic dolphins.
Kuppa Ghat, an ashram on the banks of the Ganges, is a center for followers of Maharshi Mehi Paramhans.

tourist_places.name: Vikramshila Gangetic Dolphin Sanctuary
tourist_places.location: Along the Ganges River, near Bhagalpur, Bihar

Bhojpur.title: Bhojpur, Bihar
info: Headquartered in Arrah, it is a major center for the Bhojpuri-speaking population and culture.
Historically significant for the role of its king, Veer Kunwar Singh, in the 1857 Indian Rebellion.
Located at the confluence of the Ganges and Son rivers.
Its fertile plains are a major contributor to Bihar's rice production.
The Aranya Devi Temple in Arrah is a famous local shrine.

Buxar.title: Buxar, Bihar
info: Holds immense historical and mythological importance.
The site of the pivotal Battle of Buxar in 1764, which established British supremacy in India.
According to mythology, it was the hermitage of Sage Vishvamitra, where Lord Ram killed the demoness Tadka.
A significant agricultural district on the banks of the Ganges.
The Chausa hoard, a significant discovery of Jain bronzes, was found here.

Darbhanga.title: Darbhanga, Bihar
info: The cultural heart of the Mithilanchal region.
Was the seat of the Darbhanga Raj, a powerful dynasty known for its patronage of art, music, and literature.
Famous for palaces like Nargona and Rambagh.
A major producer of Makhana (fox nuts) and fish.
Serves as a key medical and educational hub for the region, with Darbhanga Medical College and Hospital.

East Champaran.title: East Champaran, Bihar
info: Holds a prominent place in India's freedom struggle.
Its headquarters, Motihari, is where Mahatma Gandhi launched his first Satyagraha movement in 1917.
The birthplace of the renowned author George Orwell.
The world's tallest Buddhist stupa is located in Kesariya within this district.
The Raxaul border crossing is a major trade route with Nepal.

Gaya.title: Gaya, Bihar
info: A major international pilgrimage center for both Hindus and Buddhists.
Hindus visit to perform the 'Pind-daan' ritual for their ancestors at the Vishnupad Temple.
Adjacent Bodh Gaya is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, where Gautama Buddha attained enlightenment under the Bodhi tree.
The Mahabodhi Temple is a central pilgrimage destination for Buddhists worldwide.
The Barabar Caves, ancient rock-cut caves, are located in this district.

Gopalganj.title: Gopalganj, Bihar
info: An agricultural district on the banks of the Gandak river.
Its economy is driven by sugarcane cultivation and remittances from its diaspora.
The native place of former Chief Minister Lalu Prasad Yadav.
The Thawe Mandir, a famous Shakti Peeth, is a major religious site here.
It is located in the northern part of Bihar, bordering Uttar Pradesh.

Jamui.title: Jamui, Bihar
info: Characterized by hilly terrain and forests.
Known for its rich mineral deposits, including reserves of mica and gold.
Carved from Munger district in 1991.
Home to the Jain pilgrimage site at Lachhuar and the Nagi-Nakti dam bird sanctuaries.
The Giddheshwar Temple is another prominent religious site.

tourist_places.name: Nagi Dam and Nakti Dam Bird Sanctuaries

Jehanabad.title: Jehanabad, Bihar
info: Famous for the Barabar Caves, the oldest surviving rock-cut caves in India, dating back to the Mauryan Empire.
The district, once affected by Naxalism, has an economy based primarily on agriculture.
Bifurcated in 2001 to create the new district of Arwal.
It is part of the ancient Magadh region.
The Paona Math is a notable local religious institution.

Kaimur.title: Kaimur, Bihar
info: Headquartered in Bhabua, the district is defined by the Kaimur Range and is rich in forest resources.
Home to the Kaimur Wildlife Sanctuary, the largest in Bihar.
The site of the ancient Maa Mundeshwari Temple, one of the oldest functional Hindu temples in the world.
A major rice-producing area, often called part of the 'Rice Bowl of Bihar'.
The Telhar Kund waterfall is a scenic tourist spot.

Katihar.title: Katihar, Bihar
info: Located in the Seemanchal region, Katihar is a vital commercial town and a major railway junction.
One of Bihar's largest producers of jute and banana.
The Goga Lake (Gogabil), the state's first community reserve, is a significant bird habitat located here.
The district has a diverse population and a culture influenced by its proximity to Bengal.
The economy is primarily agrarian.

Khagaria.title: Khagaria, Bihar
info: Located in the plains of the Kosi River, its landscape is shaped by seven rivers.
The land is highly fertile but also extremely prone to annual floods.
A major producer of maize and chili peppers in Bihar.
The Katyayani Sthan temple at Dhamara Ghat is a famous religious site.
The district was carved out of Munger district in 1981.

Kishanganj.title: Kishanganj, Bihar
info: Situated in the 'Chicken's Neck' corridor of India, bordering Nepal and West Bengal.
The only district in Bihar that grows tea.
It also produces significant quantities of pineapple and jute.
Has the highest percentage of Muslim population among all districts in the state.
The historic Nehru Shanti Park is a well-known local landmark.

Lakhisarai.title: Lakhisarai, Bihar
info: An ancient region on the southern bank of the Ganges.
It was an important administrative and religious center during the Pala dynasty.
Famous for Ashokdham, a major temple complex dedicated to Lord Shiva.
Known for its widespread manufacturing of Sindoor (vermilion powder).
The district was formed in 1994 from Munger district.

Madhepura.title: Madhepura, Bihar
info: Deeply affected by the Kosi River, often called the 'Sorrow of Bihar'.
A major center of Yadav culture and politics.
Known for the ancient Singheshwar Sthan temple dedicated to Lord Shiva, which attracts many pilgrims.
Gained industrial importance with a large electric locomotive factory.
The district was carved out of Saharsa district in 1981.

Madhubani.title: Madhubani, Bihar
info: World-famous as the heartland of Madhubani or Mithila paintings, a traditional folk art form.
A major cultural hub of the Mithila region.
A leading producer of Makhana (fox nuts) and fish in India.
The ruined palaces of Rajnagar are a testament to its rich history under the Darbhanga Raj.
The Saurath Sabha is a site where thousands of Maithil Brahmins gather for marriage negotiations.

Munger.title: Munger, Bihar
info: A historically significant city that was the capital of Mir Qasim, the Nawab of Bengal.
Known for the grand Munger Fort and the prestigious Bihar School of Yoga.
Historically known for traditional gun manufacturing, a cigarette factory, and a railway workshop.
Sita Kund, a hot water spring, is a popular pilgrimage site.
The district is situated on the southern bank of the river Ganges.

Muzaffarpur.title: Muzaffarpur, Bihar
info: Known as the 'Lychee Kingdom' for its famous 'Shahi Litchi', which has a Geographical Indication (GI) tag.
A major commercial, educational, and healthcare hub for North Bihar.
Situated on the banks of the Budhi Gandak river.
It was a key center during the Indian independence movement.
The Baba Garibnath Dham is a prominent local temple.

Nalanda.title: Nalanda, Bihar
info: Home to the ruins of the ancient Nalanda Mahavihara, a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a great center of learning.
A key pilgrimage site for Jains, with Pawapuri being the place where Lord Mahavira attained nirvana.
The ancient city of Rajgir, the first capital of Magadha, is another major tourist and historical attraction.
The glass bridge at Rajgir has become a popular modern tourist spot.
Hiuen Tsang Memorial Hall is dedicated to the famous Chinese traveler who studied at Nalanda.

Nawada.title: Nawada, Bihar
info: Located in southern Bihar bordering Jharkhand.
Best known for the scenic Kakolat waterfall, a popular picnic spot.
The district has significant mica deposits.
Its economy is primarily based on agriculture.
The ancient Suryanarayan Dham Temple at Handiya is a notable religious site.

Patna.title: Patna, Bihar
info: The state capital with a continuous history of over 2,500 years.
Formerly known as Pataliputra, it was the capital of the Mauryan and Gupta empires.
A bustling political and commercial center on the banks of the Ganges.
Key landmarks include Golghar, Patna Museum, and the modern Bihar Museum.
Takht Sri Patna Sahib is one of the five holiest sites (Takhts) in Sikhism, being the birthplace of Guru Gobind Singh.

Purnia.title: Purnia, Bihar
info: One of the oldest districts of Bihar and a major city in the Seemanchal region.
A significant agricultural trade center, particularly for maize, jute, and makhana.
Its culture is a unique blend influenced by its proximity to Bengal and Nepal.
The Puran Devi Temple is a notable local landmark.
The city has a rich literary and cultural history.

Rohtas.title: Rohtas, Bihar
info: Often called the 'Rice Bowl of Bihar' due to high rice production.
Its headquarters, Sasaram, houses the magnificent tomb of Emperor Sher Shah Suri.
The historic Rohtasgarh Fort on the Kaimur plateau is a major landmark.
The district has abundant limestone reserves, supporting several cement factories.
The Indrapuri Barrage is one of the longest barrages in the country.

Saharsa.title: Saharsa, Bihar
info: Part of the Mithila region, its geography is dominated by the Kosi River.
A major producer of Makhana (fox nuts).
Known for the famous Ugratara Temple in Mahishi, a Shakti Peeth.
Holds a rich cultural heritage tied to Mithila traditions.
The district was formed in 1954.

Samastipur.title: Samastipur, Bihar
info: An important agricultural and commercial center.
Known for its production of tobacco, sugarcane, and wheat.
A major railway hub as the headquarters of a railway division.
Home to the renowned Dr. Rajendra Prasad Central Agricultural University in Pusa.
The Khudneshwar Sthan temple is a popular pilgrimage site.

tourist_places.name: Dr. Rajendra Prasad Central Agricultural University

Saran.title: Saran, Bihar
info: Headquartered in Chhapra, it is a culturally rich district in the Bhojpuri-speaking belt.
Famous for hosting the Sonepur Mela, one of the world's largest cattle fairs.
The fair is held annually at the confluence of the Ganga and Gandak rivers.
Has a deep archaeological heritage and a primarily agrarian economy.
The Harihar Nath Temple in Sonepur is a major pilgrimage site.

Sheikhpura.title: Sheikhpura, Bihar
info: One of the smallest districts of Bihar, known for its landscape of small granite hills.
A significant producer of onions in the state.
Its name is linked to the Sufi saint 'Hazarat Makhdum Shah Shoeb Rahamatullah Aleh'.
The district was carved out of Munger district in 1994.
The historic Arghauti Pokhar is a notable water body.

tourist_places.name: Makhdum Shah Shoeb Rahamatullah Aleh Dargah

Sheohar.title: Sheohar, Bihar
info: The smallest district of Bihar by area and one of the most densely populated.
Created in 1994 from Sitamarhi district.
Its fertile land is crisscrossed by the Bagmati and Budhi Gandak rivers.
The economy is almost entirely based on agriculture.
The Deokuli Dham (Baba Bhaveshwarnath Temple) is a significant religious site.

Sitamarhi.title: Sitamarhi, Bihar
info: A major Hindu pilgrimage center, revered as the birthplace of Goddess Sita.
The Janaki Mandir at Punaura Dham is considered the sanctified site of her birth.
The district shares a border with Nepal.
Its economy is primarily based on agriculture.
The Haleshwar Sthan is another important temple in the district.

Siwan.title: Siwan, Bihar
info: Prominently known as the birthplace of India's first President, Dr. Rajendra Prasad.
Dr. Prasad's ancestral home is in Ziradei village, which is a place of national importance.
Located in western Bihar, bordering Uttar Pradesh.
Its economy is supported by agriculture and substantial remittances from workers in the Middle East.
The Mahendra Nath Temple is a notable local pilgrimage site.

Supaul.title: Supaul, Bihar
info: Located in the heart of the Kosi division and is highly prone to flooding from the Kosi River.
The site of the Kosi Rail Mahasetu, a major engineering achievement that reconnected the Mithila region.
Separated from Saharsa district in 1991.
Its agrarian economy is dependent on paddy and makhana cultivation.
The district is part of the ancient Mithila region.

Vaishali.title: Vaishali, Bihar
info: An important archaeological site, it was the capital of the Licchavi republic.
Considered one of the first republics in the world (c. 6th century BCE).
A revered site for Buddhists, as Lord Buddha preached his last sermon and announced his parinirvana here.
A revered site for Jains, as the birthplace of Lord Mahavira.
Key attractions include an Ashokan pillar with a lion capital and the Vishwa Shanti Stupa.

West Champaran.title: West Champaran, Bihar
info: The largest district of Bihar by area, located on the India-Nepal border.
Its headquarters is Bettiah, the seat of the historic Bettiah Raj.
Home to the Valmiki National Park and Tiger Reserve, the only national park in Bihar.
Was a key center of Gandhi's Champaran Satyagraha movement.
The Bhitiharwa Ashram, established by Mahatma Gandhi, is a significant historical site.

tourist_places.name: Valmiki National Park and Tiger Reserve
